awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SDCI Net Improvement: Web10Gig - Taking TCP instrumentation to the Next Level
awd_abstract_narration:
The Web10Gig Project enables ordinary users, from the broadest range of fields and technical abilities, to effectively use the network to its full capacity.  The research associated with the Web10Gig project builds upon the very successful Web100 project, whose prototype software is still heavily used six years beyond the end of the project funding.  Under Web10Gig, the investigators produce a produce a production quality implementation of standard TCP instrumentation, based on the existing Web100 prototype, and groom it for inclusion in the Linux main line.  It eliminates barriers to development associated with the original Web100 software suite, addresses a number of weaknesses in the Web100 prototype implementation and migrates the non-kernel code to a public open source code development site where anyone can contribute future additions and improvements.


As the Web10 Gig code propagates out to all Linux users it enables network measurement and diagnosis underneath all types of Internet applications.  Like the autotuning software developed before it, it will be replicated in other operating systems, such that everybody, Linux user or not will reap to the benefits of having standard TCP instrumentation. Once incorporated into the Linux main line, the TCP instrumentation passes beyond the control of the Web10Gig investigators where maintained by the commercial world through production implementations and the researchers and developers actually using the code.

por.por_cntn:
The Web10G project was aimed at uncovering the hidden mechanisms of the TCP stack and, by doing so, reveal important information about the health and performance of Internet communications. We have accomplished this by implementing a series of instruments that hook directly into the TCP stack of the Linux kernel. Over 120 different instruments provide important data relating not only to the bandwidth but packet delay, application behavior, dropped packets, retransmitted information, round trip time, outstanding data, buffer conditions, and more. By looking beyond a simple measurement of bandwidth we believe these instrument will help users and engineers characterize TCP connection health, indicate possible failure modes, and  enable the development of application that have a hgher degree of network awareness and intelligence.

During the life of this award we were able to implement a set of over 120 different TCP instruments for the Linux kernel. The instruments provide metrics on a per flow basis for all TCP connections traversing the networking stack of the host machine. These metrics are accessed through the netlink interface; a native Linux kernel data communications method. By using this method Web10G was able to provide metrics on hundreds of thousands of concurrent connections while incurring minimal overhead.

In order to facilitate application development we also developed an API library with a focus on simplicity and functionality. This library provides straightforward mechanisms for the creation of new instrumentation sessions, masking of polled instruments, listing of active connections, and associated functionality. The library is full demonstrated in example and utility applications included with the library's source code.

The grant also funded the development of the Insight application. Insight allows users on Web10G enabled hosts to visualize local TCP connections via a world map. Users are able to quickly identify TCP connections with high rates of loss and, in enabled environments, report TCP stack metrics to network engineers for analysis. While this tool has not seen wide spread adoption it has proven to be a valid basis for ongoing research.

Lastly, the team was dedicated to presenting this work to the Linux community for inclusion into the mainline kernel source tree. While the initial submission was rejected the team was invited to present their work to the Linux networking community at the NetDev conference in 2015. Discussions there clearly indicated that TCP instrumentation would be a valuable addition to the networking stack. We received important guidance as to how to improve and revise the Web10G kernel code. The team, though no longer directly funded, continues to work towards mainline inclusion of the Web10G code.

Modified by: Christopher J Rapier
